abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Safety Net Reform
            Project for West Bank and Gaza were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. There were ten
            lessons learned: 1) Conditional cash transfers are not the
            best approach in all cases. 2) It is important to take
            advantage of existing projects' experience when
            designing the implementation arrangements of new projects.
            3) Social safety net (SSN) instruments, such as cash
            transfer schemes, need to be in place and tested before a
            crisis so that they will be ready for quick scale up during
            a crisis. 4) Non-politicized, means-tested targeting
            modalities are useful in reassuring donors that the
            necessary safeguards are in place to ensure that the poorest
            and most vulnerable households receive assistance. 5)
            Structural reform of the SSN may be necessary and important.
            6) The Bank can be effective in providing emergency
            assistance when the appropriate structures are in place,
            even in an environment of weak governance. 7) Additional
            effort and resources may be required to ensure that
            individuals in the lowest income tiers receive priority
            assistance. 8) Governments should carefully consider the
            costs associated with maintaining cash assistance programs
            in the long-term, as donor assistance may not be provided
            for extended periods of time. 9) Close supervision and
            flexibility in responding to changing situations are
            important to ensure that the Project is successfully
            implemented. 10) Ensuring in-house development of the MIS
            and expertise related to its management and operation is
            useful in promoting flexibility and adaptability when facing
            any modifications in the program design and/or targeting mechanism.
